messageBody:
You may need to change your code to make it easier to test. Here is how
a typical test for the logic you described would go...

Create objects and get references to singletons used in the use case.

Use mutators (set methods) to manipulate the objects to a particular
state.

Call the get template method

Assert that the correct template has been selected.

Create a different test for each template, or even more than one if you
have complex rules.



-----Original Message-----
From: Kmiec, Christopher [mailto:chris.kmiec@...]
Sent: 13 August 2001 19:33
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: [junit] newbie question


Hello,

I'm looking into JUnit to test a new email component I wrote. I read
through
the Money example and it makes sense but what I'm trying to test is a
little
different.

I have a class which is responsible for deciding which email template to
use
based on some complex business rules. The selected template is never
stored
in the class itself (this is a singleton object). Instead, it's passed
to
another method in another class which populates the template with
dynamic
data and sends the email out.

Any ideas on how JUnit could be useful to make sure that the correct
templates are always selected and that the emails are actually sent?

Thanks.
--Chris
